sen.j: 中務省（なかつかさしょう）は律令制における日本の官制のひとつ。
sen.e: Nakatsukasa-sho (Ministry of Central Affairs, "中務省" in the Chinese characters) was a government-regulated organization under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo codes).

Nakatsukasa-sho (Ministry of Central Affairs, "中務省" in the Chinese characters) was a government-regulated organization under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo codes).

Nakatsukasa-sho (Ministry of Central Affairs, "中務省" in the Chinese characters) was a government-regulated organization under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo codes).

sen.j: 和名はナカノマツリゴトノツカサ。
sen.e: It was also called by a Japanese name, 'Naka-no-matsurigoto-no-tukasa.'
It was also called by a Japanese name, 'Naka no matsurigoto no tukasa.'
sen.cmt: ハイフンをとり、Naka no matsurigoto no tukasaとしました。
sen.e: It was also called by a Japanese name, 'Naka no matsurigoto no tukasa.'

sen.j: 「中」は禁中の意。
sen.e: The Chinese character '中' of "中務省" has a meaning of the Imperial Court.
The Chinese character '中' of "中務省" has a meaning of the Imperial Court.
The Chinese character '中' of "中務省" has a meaning of the Imperial Court.

sen.j: 天皇の補佐や、詔勅の宣下や叙位など、朝廷に関する職務の全般を担っていた為に、八省の中でも最も重要な省である。
sen.e: Nakatsukasa-sho was regarded as the most important ministry among eight central ministries, because it administered all duties related to the Imperial Court, such as assisting the Emperor, proclaiming the imperial edict, conferring the court rank.

Nakatsukasa-sho was regarded as the most important ministry among the eight central ministries, because it administered all duties related to the Imperial Court, such as assisting the Emperor, proclaiming the imperial edict, conferring the court rank.
sen.cmt: among the eight central ministriesとしました。
sen.e: Nakatsukasa-sho was regarded as the most important ministry among the eight central ministries, because it administered all duties related to the Imperial Court, such as assisting the Emperor, proclaiming the imperial edict, conferring the court rank.

sen.j: 一説には大宝律令以前には宮内省とともに六省の上にあったとする説もある。
sen.e: There is a theory that Nakatsukasa-sho along with Kunai-sho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) was ranked higher than other six ministries before the establishment of Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code).

There is a theory that Nakatsukasa-sho along with Kunai-sho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) was ranked higher than other six ministries before the establishment of Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code).

There is a theory that Nakatsukasa-sho along with Kunai-sho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) was ranked higher than other six ministries before the establishment of Taiho Ritsuryo (Taiho Code).

sen.j: そのためこの官庁の長官である中務卿（正四位上相当）は平安時代以降はもっぱら四品以上の親王から任命されることとなっていた。
sen.e: Therefore, the Nakatsukasa-Kyo (corresponding to Shoshiinojo [Senior Fourth Rank Upper Grade]), the Secretary of Nakatsukasa-sho, was conventionally chosen from the Imperial Princes with a rank equivalent to or higher than Shihon (the fourth rank of Imperial Princes' rank) exclusively in and after the Heian period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。ウエブでは「位階」ではなく「正四位上」および「四品」でしたので訂正しました。
sen.e: Therefore, the Nakatsukasa-Kyo (corresponding to Shoshiinojo [Senior Fourth Rank Upper Grade]), the Secretary of Nakatsukasa-sho, was conventionally chosen from the Imperial Princes with a rank equivalent to or higher than Shihon (the fourth rank of Imperial Princes' rank) exclusively in and after the Heian period.

Therefore, the Nakatsukasa-Kyo (corresponding to Shoshiinojo [Senior Fourth Rank Upper Grade]), the Secretary of Nakatsukasa-sho, was conventionally chosen from the Imperial Princes with a rank equivalent to or higher than Shihon (the fourth rank of Imperial Princes' rank) exclusively in and after the Heian period.

sen.j: 欠員が生じても適当な親王が出るまでは空席とされた。
sen.e: Even if the post became vacant, it remained unfilled until an Imperial Prince suitable for the post appeared.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Even if the post became vacant, it remained unfilled until an Imperial Prince suitable for the post appeared.
Even if the post became vacant, it remained unfilled until an Imperial Prince suitable for the post appeared.

sen.j: また、この官庁は詔勅の施行から後宮女官の人事まで朝廷の事務一般を扱うために職掌が広かった。
sen.e: This minister had to cover extensive duties, because it managed the general clerical works related to the Imperial Court from enforcement of the imperial edict to the personnel affairs concerning court ladies in Kokyu (empress's residence).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。後列より文章を移動し、分割し直しました。
sen.e: This ministry had to cover extensive duties, because it managed the general clerical works related to the Imperial Court from enforcement of the imperial edict to the personnel affairs concerning court ladies in Kokyu (empress's residence).

This ministry had to cover extensive duties, because it managed the general clerical works related to the Imperial Court from enforcement of the imperial edict to the personnel affairs concerning court ladies in Kokyu (empress's residence).

sen.j: このため輔（すけ）・丞（じょう）・録（さかん）の四等官（他の日本の官制の四等官と比較して官位相当は一段高く設定されている。）のほかに、天皇に近侍する侍従、宮中の警備、雑役及び行幸の際の警護役である内舎人、詔勅や宣命及び位記を作成する内記等、大蔵省や内蔵寮（くらりょう）等の出納を行う監物等、駅鈴や伝符の出納たを行う主鈴や典鑰が中務省の品官（ほんかん）とされた。
sen.e: Therefore, in addition to Shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks, the official court ranks conferred to the Shitokan of Nakatsukasa-sho were higher than Shitokan in other ministries) consisting of Suke, Jo and Sakan, the following posts were counted among Honkan (government posts): Jiju (chamberlain); officials attending the Emperor, Udoneri (Ministerial equerry); officials taking charge of the Imperial Court defense and miscellaneous jobs and guarding an imperial visit, Naiki and others; officials engaged in drafting the two types of imperial edict (one was written in the classical Chinese and the other was in the Japanese syllabary) and the court rank diploma, Kenmotsu and others; officials engaged in accounts of Okura-sho (Ministry of the Treasury), Kura-ryo (Bureau of Palace Storehouses), etc., Shurei and Tenyaku; officials managing Ekirei (bells set in stations used for supplying horses), Denfu (certification for lending horses), accounts, etc.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。「駅鈴や伝符の出納たを」がわかりません。さらに駅鈴、伝符とも出納と関係がつきません。よって訳は駅鈴、伝符、出納等としました。
sen.e: Therefore, in addition to Shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks, the official court ranks conferred to the Shitokan of Nakatsukasa-sho were higher than Shitokan in other ministries) consisting of Suke, Jo and Sakan, the following posts were counted among Honkan (government posts): Jiju (chamberlain); officials attending the Emperor, Udoneri (Ministerial equerry); officials taking charge of the Imperial Court defense and miscellaneous jobs and guarding an imperial visit, Naiki and others; officials engaged in drafting the two types of imperial edict (one was written in the classical Chinese and the other was in the Japanese syllabary) and the court rank diploma, Kenmotsu and others; officials engaged in accounts of Okura-sho (Ministry of the Treasury), Kura-ryo (Bureau of Palace Storehouses), etc., Shurei and Tenyaku; officials managing Ekirei (bells set in stations used for supplying horses), Denfu (certification for lending horses), etc.
sen.cmt: ここでの「出納」は「物品の出し入れを役とした者」の意と思われますので、accountsを削除し、"managing Ekirei (bells set in stations used for supplying horses), Denfu (certification for lending horses), etc."のみとしました。(参考: http://dictionary.goo.ne.jp/leaf/jn/91478/m0u/%E5%87%BA%E9%A6%AC/)
sen.e: Therefore, in addition to Shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks, the official court ranks conferred to the Shitokan of Nakatsukasa-sho were higher than Shitokan in other ministries) consisting of Suke, Jo and Sakan, the following posts were counted among Honkan (government posts): Jiju (chamberlain); officials attending the Emperor, Udoneri (Ministerial equerry); officials taking charge of the Imperial Court defense and miscellaneous jobs and guarding an imperial visit, Naiki and others; officials engaged in drafting the two types of imperial edict (one was written in the classical Chinese and the other was in the Japanese syllabary) and the court rank diploma, Kenmotsu and others; officials engaged in accounts of Okura-sho (Ministry of the Treasury), Kura-ryo (Bureau of Palace Storehouses), etc., Shurei and Tenyaku; officials managing Ekirei (bells set in stations used for supplying horses), Denfu (certification for lending horses), etc.

sen.j: なお、天皇の側近たる侍従及び天皇の警護を行う内舎人は帯剣することを義務付けられていた。
sen.e: Meanwhile, the Udoneri guarding the Emperor and the Jiju, attendants of the emperor, was obliged to wear a sword.
Meanwhile, the Udoneri guarding the Emperor and the Jiju, attendants of the Emperor, was obliged to wear a sword.
Meanwhile, the Udoneri guarding the Emperor and the Jiju, attendants of the Emperor, was obliged to wear a sword.

sen.j: この省の被官の官司は令制では1職 (律令制)6寮 (律令制)3司あった。
sen.e: Government offices under high-ranked offices in Nakatsukasa-sho were categorized into one-shiki (the Ritsuryo system), six-ryo (the Ritsuryo system) and three-shi under the Ritsuryo system.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Government offices under high-ranked offices in Nakatsukasa-sho were categorized into one-shiki (the Ritsuryo system), six-ryo (the Ritsuryo system) and three-shi under the Ritsuryo system.
Government offices under high-ranked offices in Nakatsukasa-sho were categorized into one-shiki (the Ritsuryo system), six-ryo (the Ritsuryo system) and three-shi under the Ritsuryo system.

sen.j: しかし統廃合により1職6寮に減った。
sen.e: However, this system was later streamlined to decrease the number of categories to one-shiki and six-ryo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: However, this system was later streamlined to decrease the number of categories to one-shiki and six-ryo.
However, this system was later streamlined to decrease the number of categories to one-shiki and six-ryo.
